thread.title: Mitchell International airport loses nearly half of its flights since 2011: Wall Street Journal
thread.title_full: Mitchell International airport loses nearly half of its flights since 2011: Wall Street Journal

author: Natalie Wickman
title: Mitchell International airport loses nearly half of its flights since 2011: Wall Street Journal
text:
Scott Paulus The number of flights departing General Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee hasâ€¦ more General Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee has lost nearly half of its weekly flights since 2011, ranking Mitchell third in a report from the Wall Street Journal Wednesday about service level cuts at major U.S. airports. Milwaukee's airport lost 45.2 percent of its flights according to the report, which details changes in the number of weekly departures for notable U.S. cities during the third week of July between 2011 and 2015. The country's airlines are flying 11,475 fewer domestic flights this year when comparing the third weeks of July 2011 and 2015. The flight tracking and data firm masFlight collected data for the report. The U.S. Justice Department is investigating whether airlines keep prices artificially high by conspiring to offer fewer flights. Delta, American, Southwest and United have denied wrongdoing. The Memphis International Airport in Tennessee ranked first in the report, losing 66 percent of its flights. The Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport in Virginia came in second with a loss of 51.1 percent. The airport that has the most flight additions since 2011 is St. Pete-Clearwater International in Florida, with a gain of 93.9 percent.
